tasks.existing_task_content:
# Math: Trigonometric functions (Single-select CQ)

| **Metadata** | For researchers only |
|---|---|
| **Domain** | STEM Education |
| **Use case** | Math |
| **Use case description** | Learn to apply mathematical concepts and formulas to solve problems. |
| **Knowledge dimensions** | Conceptual |
| **Reference material filename** | trigonometry-basics.pdf |
| **Reference material source** | The RM is drawn from The Princeton Review (4ed) |
| **Comprehension quiz source** | the CQs are drawn from Princeton Review GRE, ETS official practice tests, Princeton Review SAT (2014), Barron's SAT (12ed), and Kaplan's SAT (10ed). |
| **Task inspiration** | Trigonometry is a common area taught in high schools and included in AMC; however, it is not a common requirement for SAT or GRE General, reducing the possibility of participants having strong priors. |
| **AI system prompt** | You are a helpful AI assistant that provides clear, informative, and educational information. |

| **Task data** | Displayed for participants  |
|---|---|
| **Task ID** | trigonometry-basics-singleselect |
| **Task title** | Trigonometric functions |
| **Task topic** | Trigonometric functions |
| **Task scenario** | You are assisting a student learning about fundamental math topics that bridges between high-school and university. One of the topic is trigonometric functions. |
| **Task description** | In math, trigonometry concerns the relationships between angles and side lengths of triangles. In this task, you will need to learn as much as you can about fundamental trigonometric functions and how to apply them to triangles to solve problems. |
| **Task instruction for Explainer** | You will need to provide clear and accurate information about fundamental trigonometric functions to your partner later. Your partner may come with specific questions with details, including but not exhaustive of the relationships between different functions and some special triangles, so pay attention to these details. |
| **Task instruction for Learner** | Your partner will have gained knowledge about fundamental trigonometric functions, and you will have to learn from them by asking them to explain. Beyond general information, you should learn about how to solve problems that concern the following: 1. Special right triangle with angles like 30-60-90. 2. Isosceles right triangles (right triangles with two equal sides). 3. Relationships between trigonometric functions. |
| **Formulas** | {"Sine (right triangle)": "$\sin \theta = \frac{\text{opposite}}{\text{hypotenuse}}$", "Cosine (right triangle)": "$\cos \theta = \frac{\text{adjacent}}{\text{hypotenuse}}$"} |

tasks.reference_material_content:
TRIGONOMETRY
Although trigonometry began as the study of triangles, the usefulness of the trigonometric functions now
extends far beyond this simple geometric form. We'll begin our study by reviewing the definitions of the
trig functions, first with acute angles in right triangles and then with arbitrary angles and real numbers.
TRIG fuNCTIONS OF AcuTE ANGLES
The classical definitions of the six trig functions-sine, cosine, tangent, cosecant, secant, and cotangent­
use the lengths of the sides of a right triangle. In the figure below, triangle ABC is a right triangle with
a
its right angle at C. The lengths of the legs BC and AC are denoted and respectively, and the length

Angles A and Bare complementary (that is, the sum of their measures is 90°), and notice that sin A =
cos B. That is, the sine of B's complement (namely, A) is cos B, which is where the name "cosine" comes
from (complement's sine). The same is true for the other pairs of cofunctions-tangent and cotangent,
secant and cosecant. You'll also notice certain reciprocal relationships among the functions. Cosecant is
the reciprocal of sine, secant is the reciprocal of cosine, and cotangent is the reciprocal of tangent. Finally,
all of the trig functions can be written in terms of sine and cosine: The reciprocal relationships take care
of secant and cosecant, and it's easy to see that tangent is the ratio of sine to cosine, and cotangent is the
ratio of cosine to sine.
Two special right triangles allow us to determine the numerical values of the trig functions of the
angles 30°, 45°, and 60°.
